references.B98PET01NCGP: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
references.A87HIG02NAUS: Highton, R. 1987. PLETHODON WEHRLEI. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 402.1-402.3.
references.B80MAR01NAUS: Martof, B. S., W. M. Palmer, J. R. Bailey, and J. R. Harrison, III. 1980. Amphibians and reptiles of the Carolinas and Virginia. University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 264 pp.
references.B87GRE01NAUS: Green, N. B., and T. K. Pauley. 1987. Amphibians and reptiles in West Virginia. University of Pittsburg Press, Pittsburg, Pennsylvania. xi + 241 pp.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.B96RED01NAUS: Redmond, W. H., and A. F. Scott. 1996. Atlas of amphibians in Tennessee. The Center for Field Biology, Austin Peay State University, Miscellaneous Publication Number 12. v + 94 pp.

habitat_description: Wehrle's salamander is found in upland forests near the entrances of caves, among rock outcrops, and mountain hillsides (Martof et al. 1980, Petranka 1998).  It is perhaps most frequently found in rocky gorges that are covered with mesic hardwood forest (Redmond and Scott 1996), but red spruce-yellow birch and dry forest types are also suitable (Petranka 1998).  They are found in rock crevices, under rocks, logs, and leaves, and in twilight zone of caves (at lower elevations).  Courtship occurs in the fall and spring and eggs are laid in damp logs, moss, cave crevices, and other protected sites.  The eggs are laid from March to April in New York and in January-March in Pennsylvania.  Wehrle’s salamander reaches sexual maturity in 4-5 years.  In West Virginia, they have been found at sites between 183 and 1463 m (Petranks 1998) Stacy Smith, 15April05 and N. Tarr, 25November2012.
